page.title: 11LUFFNESS ESTATE
page.content: This ancient estate occupies the land to the east of the village. There was a 12th century castle here, very large and important, a seat of the Earls of Dunbar and March, the moat for which and vestiges of the angle towers remain. A ruined priory which was founded in 1268 is to be discovered in the grounds. The castle was partially demolished in 1537, by the victorious English after the Battle of Pinkie, but the two lower storeys of the Keep, with ten-foot thick walls defied the demolishers and are incorporated in the present fortified house, which was erected in 1584. The Hope family gained possession of the estate in 1713 and still hold it. The 17th century garden is especially fine and opens, within the Scottish Gardens scheme, to the general public.
